SENT.plain: A 30 year old women, beginning her 19th day postpartum, was admitted for lowering of alertness
The day before she complained of cephalalagia
Neurologic examination showed pyramidal tract signs on the right part of the body, a bilateral Babinski sign, and central oculomotor palsy
She started a treatment by nasal pulverization of phenylephrine, a sympathomimetic vasoconstrictor, one week before, and took bromocriptine (5 mg per day) from childbirth to second week postpartum
Lumbar puncture showed a high level of proteins, from transsudative origin
Cerebral angiography showed a beading aspect of arterial branches, especially in the left middle cerebral artery territory
Two days after drug withdrawal, the patient recovered
This angiographic pattern has already been described in cases of cerebral angiopathy due to sympathomimetic drug abuse, and in cases of postpartum cerebral angiopathy
The chronology, in our case, makes the responsibility of the phenylephrine very likely
Nonetheless, ergot derivatives (i.e. ergonovine, bromocriptine) have also been accused of giving cerebral postpartum angiopathy
In our case, we think that bromocriptine may have triggered the cerebral angiopathy due to phenylephrine
